texts.definition: Game Elements or game events that kill or damage avatars and units.
markups: <style="Definition">Game Elements or game events that kill or damage avatars and units.</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> are hidden dangers in game environments that can damage people and items, potentially killing or destroying them. Some are diegetically explained as being constructed with the intention of being traps while others are simply dangerous environments. Examples of <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> include pits, falling blocks, lava, fire, acid, steam, machinery, crushing presses, fast-moving vehicles, and collapsing bridges, but many more are possible.

The adventure game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Another%20World">Another World</link></style> forces players to explore a dangerous alien world where any wrong movement can lead to the triggering of some sort of <style="CurrentLink">Trap</style>.

Games which consist of exploring dungeons, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NetHack">NetHack</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Oblivion">Oblivion</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style> all have <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style>. Examples include pits, collapsing roofs, and chests that do not contain loot but instead are "Mimics" that attack the players' characters. The "Grimtooth" line of systemless roleplaying supplements consist entirely of traps.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Platform%20Games">Platform games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20Sunshine">Super Mario Sunshine</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Legend%20of%20Zelda:%20The%20Wind%20Waker">The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker</link></style> are filled with a wide variety of deadly <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style>.

The tracks in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Monkey%20Ball%20series">Super Monkey Ball series</link></style> are hovering high above the ground, effectively surrounding the tracks with a deadly <style="CurrentLink">Trap</style>. The survivors played in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> are not always high above ground, but when they are there are no rails preventing wrong steps to cause them to end up hanging helpless from ledges until saved by others.
Ghost Stories is an example of where players can place Traps, in this case Buddha figurines kill most types of ghosts that encounter the figurines.

<style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> can be divided into three categories: those that are visible and whose effects are clear, those that can be found by noticing differences from the surrounding environment of the trap, and those that cannot be noticed before they are activated. The first type, exemplified by game elements such as crushers, flame dischargers, and so on that follow a certain pattern in activation, allows players to bypass or deactivate them as long as they successful with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="rhythm-based-actions">Rhythm-Based Actions</link></style>. The second type, which can be exemplified by (badly) camouflaged pits, require players to be observant of <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. The last type, often <style="Link"><link="red-herrings">Red Herrings</link></style> and which can be exemplified by false <style="Link"><link="power-ups">Power-Ups</link></style> or <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> activated by counter-weights when picking up <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style>, creates <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> but also promotes <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style> to remember the location of the trap. Triggering the <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> typically lead to <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> and can also lead to instant deaths, e.g. losses of <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. While instantly killing players with <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> not possible to notice before they are sprung may seem harsh, this has been under in games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Another%20World">Another World</link></style>, to require players to combine <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leaps%20of%20Faith">Leaps of Faith</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorize</link></style> in order to solve problems. The negative effects can of course be limited to specific type of game elements: those belonging to players, those representing <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, or more complex combinations.

Either <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> can be used to all of the categories, but <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style> are noteworthy in that they can allow players to construct <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> during gameplay using a game's rules for physics. <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> are not <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> in themselves, but they can works as such if they are placed so they become <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> for those moving too fast. <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style> are also interesting since they can be <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> because they are destructible, e.g. <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> hiding pits, but also be other types of <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> that happen to be <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style> and in the latter case this can be used to spring the traps on others.

<style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> can be modulated in several ways, for example by being triggered by interrupting <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style> between the <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> and other objects, or having <style="Link"><link="delayed-effects">Delayed Effects</link></style> to let players have a chance of <style="Link"><link="evade">Evading</link></style> them. Note that this does not always have to be through <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>, some games (e.g. the fourth installment in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Resident%20Evil%20series">Resident Evil series</link></style>) have <style="Link"><link="quick-time-events">Quick Time Events</link></style> to avoid <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style>.  <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> with <style="Link"><link="delayed-effects">Delayed Effects</link></style> can also have the activation be a form of <style="Link"><link="interruptible-actions">Interruptible Action</link></style> to allow players <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> to disarm the <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> before they have effect. <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> in their appearance, and the <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style> their effects have had on their surroundings, can give players forewarning of the danger the <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> represent.

<style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> can be used to limit the players' accessible area, i.e. create <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>, either by acting as a barrier to an area or by being <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> that affect the whole area, e.g. by being a lake of acid. Accessible routes can be hidden this types of <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> which can be navigated by combinations of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leap%20of%20Faith">Leap of Faith</link></style> actions and <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="shrinking-game-worlds">Shrinking Game Worlds</link></style> can take the form of <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style>, which either seals off game areas, e.g., collapsing bridges or cave-ins, or kill those unfortunate to be in the areas removed. Less commonly, <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> can be used to open up game areas, e.g., a fallen rock exposes a tunnel. This can be used to enforce the <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> of games and to create or open up <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> can be used to help <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> goals and can make it possible to achieve <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goals without directly attacking opponents.

It is important to note that the pattern <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> relates to gameplay and not narration, so <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> do not have to be constructions made purposely to be traps, they can also be natural environments that are disturbed such as rock falls or setup by hostile <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>.

While some <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> require <style="Link"><link="rhythm-based-actions">Rhythm-Based Actions</link></style> to avoid, games built around <style="Link"><link="rhythm-based-actions">Rhythm-Based Actions</link></style> sometimes instead explain failures of performing these actions as the triggering of <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style>.

Since <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> can cause <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>, this can be used as part of <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> and especially to enact <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="scripted-information-sequences">Scripted Information Sequences</link></style> can be used to create dramatic <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style>, e.g. huge stones rolling towards the players' <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> add game elements to <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> that threaten players with <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>, but they can also threaten to directly lead to losses of <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. By doing so, they provide <style="Link"><link="pve">PvE</link></style> gameplay unless the placement of the <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> can be traced to other players.

Common objects of <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> goals, <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> give players restricted <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style> within their immediate surrounding and can require players into more careful or complex <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>, or make parts of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> into <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>. This quite naturally can make both <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="rescue">Rescue</link></style> goals more dangerous. <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> that can be activated again and again introduce game elements that are <style="Link"><link="consumers">Consumers</link></style> into <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and promotes <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style> of their locations. Those seemingly <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style> that can be in fact be navigated give rise to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leaps%20of%20Faith">Leaps of Faith</link></style> in order to provide information to <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorize</link></style>.

Depending on whether the trap is known to the player, <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> can cause <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> in the form of <style="Link"><link="surprise-attacks">Surprise Attacks</link></style>, and those that are triggered but have <style="Link"><link="delayed-effects">Delayed Effects</link></style> can cause <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> that mask themselves as useful <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> or beneficial <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> are <style="Link"><link="red-herrings">Red Herrings</link></style>. Triggered <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> are examples of <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style> when the activation of the effect is not an <style="Link"><link="interruptible-actions">Interruptible Action</link></style> nor is it possible to <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> their effects.

When <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style> can be used to construct <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style>, this provides <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> for players. <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> that are <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style> may not provide as much <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> but can offer gameplay options to those engaging in <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>. When <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> can be used in these ways by players, or simply moved safely in some fashion, they can be used to help solve <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> goals. The <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> that take time to unfold, e.g. by being <style="Link"><link="scripted-information-sequences">Scripted Information Sequences</link></style> or having <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style>, are <style="Link"><link="attention-demanding-gameplay">Attention Demanding Gameplay</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style> cannot be combined with <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style>, since the presence of the <style="CurrentLink">Traps</style> would make the locations unsafe.

<style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="consumers">Consumers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leaps%20of%20Faith">Leaps of Faith</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="pve">PvE</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="red-herrings">Red Herrings</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="surprise-attacks">Surprise Attacks</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="scripted-information-sequences">Scripted Information Sequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="shrinking-game-worlds">Shrinking Game Worlds</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="delayed-effects">Delayed Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="interruptible-actions">Interruptible Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="quick-time-events">Quick Time Events</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rhythm-based-actions">Rhythm-Based Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style>
